SENT.plain: Mutations in codons 12 or 13 of the first exon of the N-RAS gene have been reported in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) in frequencies that vary between 9% and 40% depending on the techniques used in analysis
Gene amplification and direct sequencing provides the only unambiguous method of detecting those mutations that induce amino acid alterations
Using this technique, we analyzed 21 MDS patients for mutations in exon-1 of N-RAS
Codon 12 mutations substituting aspartic acid (GAT) for glycine (GGT) were found in four cases, and a codon 13 mutation substituting alanine (GCT) for glycine (GGT) was detected in one patient
We conclude that N-RAS exon-1 mutations in one patient
We conclude that N-RAS exon-1 mutations producing amino acid changes occur in about 20% to 25% of MDS cases
